Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Thermodynamic and Thermal Expansion Behavior of Mineral Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research seeks to understand how earth materials, and the earth itself, behave as a function of temperature and pressure. Such information allows prediction of the conditions under which the earth's minerals form and how their coexistence are interpreted. A significant number of studies have been developed specifically for undergraduate participation. These experiences teach students how research is conducted and why results are important in the context of ethical scientific behavior. Research involvement also is important to the enthusiasm of students for science and their retention in science. All but one of the students involved in past projects in this laboratory, more than 50% of them women, remain involved in science today. Additionally, it is important for any teacher to remain engaged in her/his discipline throughout a professional lifetime. The collective research experiences of a scientist enrich his/her professional life, but just as importantly benefit his/her students as a result of the knowledge, experience, and enthusiasm brought to the classroom.

The principal purpose of this laboratory is the collection of thermodynamic data on geologically important materials utilizing acid solution calorimetric experimentation conducted at 50 Â°C. Such data contribute to determination of the conditions in the earth under which materials occur, even at great depths below the surface. One focus is on "thermodynamic mixing properties" of crystalline solutions, as relatively few directly measured thermodynamic data exist for mid-compositional members of mineral series. The latter are critical to thermodynamic modeling, and required for the accurate prediction of mineral occurrences for intermediate members of solid solution series. In addition, calorimetric data help clarify the fundamental energetic bases of mineral formation, knowledge that can be applied to additional materials whose thermodynamic properties have not been measured. A second component of this work involves undergraduate-oriented high-temperature X-ray investigations on the thermal expansion of minerals. These will yield information critical to understanding how mineral structures behave at the elevated temperatures that exist below the earth's surface. They also will contribute to an understanding of the mechanisms through which expansion takes place. Finally, the latter studies will yield volumes of mixing for mineral series as a function of temperature.

POR.DRECONTENT:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT:

The principal purpose of this laboratory is the collection of thermodynamic data on geologically important materials. One focus is on "mixing properties" of minerals that vary in chemical composition between two end members; indeed, few mineral series exist on which highly precise directly measured thermodynamic mixing quantities have been collected. The latter are critical to thermodynamic modeling and required for the accurate calculation of phase equilibria involving compositionally intermediate members of mineral series. Such data help geologists make sense of mineral formation deep in the earth over hundreds of millions, even billions, of years.

We proposed to study the mineral apatite, [Ca5(PO4)3(F,Cl,OH)], one of the most common minerals in the earth. Research on such a mineral has wide application to igneous, metamorphic and hydrothermal environments. Moreover, apatite is an essential component of the earth's phosphorous cycle, a significant substance in materials science, agricultural and other industries, and, finally, the main chemical compound that composes human teeth and bones. During the grant period two apatite solid-solution series were examined: Fluor-chlor samples, [Ca5(PO4)3(F,Cl], and fluor-hydroxyl samples, [Ca5(PO4)3(F,OH]. Solution calorimetric measurements were conducted in 20.0% HCl. Accompanying room- temperature X-ray powder diffraction measurements were made to measure unit-cell volumes as well as volumes of mixing. Thermal expansion measurements on the same specimens, using X-ray measurements made at high temperature, allowed modeling of mineral behavior at high temperature. The first four publications listed below resulted from this work. In addition to the apatite work, we completed publication of results on feldspar thermal expansion research begun during our previous NSF grant, the fifth reference below.

Hovis, G., Abraham, T., Hudacek, W., Wildermuth, S., Scott, B., Altomare, C., Medford, A., Conlon, M., Morris, M., Leaman, A., Almer, C., Tomaino, G., Harlov, D. (2015) Thermal expansion of F-Cl apatite crystalline solutions. American Mineralogist, v. 100, pp. 1040-1046.

Hovis, G.L., Scott, B.T., Altomare, C.M., Leaman, A.R., Morris, M.D., Tomaino, G.P., McCubbin, F.M. (2014) Thermal expansion of fluorapatite-hydroxyl-apatite crystalline solutions. American Mineralogist, v. 99, pp. 2171-2175.

Hovis, G.L., McCubbin, F., Nekvasil, H., Ustunisik, G., Woerner, W., Lindsley, D.H. (2014) A novel technique for fluorapatite synthesis and the thermo-dynamic mixing behavior of F-OH apatite crystalline solutions. American Mineralogist, v. 99, pp. 890-897.

Hovis, G.L., Harlov, D. (2010) Solution calorimetric investigation of fluor-chlorapatite crystalline solutions. American Mineralogist, v. 95, pp. 946-952.

Hovis, G.L., Medford, A., Conlon, M., Tether, A., Romanoski, A. (2010) Principles of thermal expansion in the feldspar system. American Mineralogist, v. 95, pp. 1060-1068.

A second set of projects during this grant period involved thermal expansion measurements on several isostructural silicate mineral groups, including garnet, olivine, pyroxene, amphibole, and tourmaline. We asked the question: How does chemical composition affect the rate of thermal expansion within groups that have exactly the same atomic structure? A total of 53 minerals were studied. One thousand seven X-ray scans were made at high temperature in order to do this work. Research results were presented in April, 2018, at the European Geosciences Union General Assembly. Nine present and former Lafayette College undergraduates, four women and five men, worked on this project and were coauthors of that poster presentation:

Hovis, G., Altomare, C., Almer, C., Leaman, A., Morris, M., Maksymiw, N., Morris, D., Jackson, K., Scott, B., and Tomaino, G. (2018) Effects of chemical composition on variation in thermal expansion for minerals in the garnet, olivine, pyroxene, amphibole, and tourmaline systems. Geophysical Research Abstracts 20, EGU2018-3128

Results of this study are in preparation for publication in extended journal form.

One additional publication was produced during the current grant period:

Hovis, G. (2017) A refined view of the thermodynamic mixing quantities for alkali feldspars and the quandary of excess configurational entropy. American Journal of Science, v. 317, pp. 597-640.

Although not part of research under the current grant, the production of this paper culminates a lifetime of research on the feldspar mineral system, all supported by the National Science Foundation. The PI sees this as very significant work.

[NOTE: 28 student names are listed as coauthors in the publications above.]

 

BROADER IMPACTS:

As noted in our original proposal, beyond the scientific value of studies undertaken, projects developed specifically for undergraduate participation are valuable because they teach students how to properly conduct research and why scientific data are important. Research involvement also is important to the enthusiasm of students for science and their retention in science. Nearly all of the students involved in past projects in this laboratory going back to the mid-1990s (50% of them women) remain involved in science today. Moreover, it is important for any teacher to remain engaged in her/his discipline throughout a professional lifetime. The collective research experiences of a scientist not only enrich his/her professional life, but also benefit his/her students as a result of the knowledge, experience, and enthusiasm brought back to the classroom.
